hints_html:
There are (at least) two distinct ways to solve this.

Option 1: Start with a trigonometric substitution.

Option 2: Use partial fractions.

Option 1: Your first trigonometric substitution should make use of the fact that \(a^2+a^2\tan^2\theta = a^2\sec^2\theta.\)

Option 2: How do set up partial fraction when the denominator does not factor into linear factors?

question: 3 (c)
sols_html:
We recognize a denominator of the form \(x^2+a^2\) and so we attempt a trigonometric substitution of the form

\[\begin{aligned} x = 2\tan \theta, \quad dx = 2\sec^2 \theta\,d\theta.\end{aligned}\]

Then the integral becomes

\[\begin{aligned} \int \frac{dx}{x(x^2+4)} &= \int \frac{2\sec^2 \theta\,d\theta}{2\tan \theta \underbrace{(4\tan^2\theta+4)}_{=4\sec^2\theta}} \\ &= \int \frac{d\theta}{4\tan\theta} = \frac14 \int \frac{\cos \theta\,d\theta}{\sin \theta}.\end{aligned}\]

To solve this integral we use another substitution:

\[\begin{aligned} u = \sin \theta, \quad du = \cos \theta\,d\theta,\end{aligned}\]

to obtain

\[\begin{aligned} \frac14 \int \frac{\cos \theta\,d\theta}{\sin \theta} &= \frac14 \int \frac{\cos \theta\,du}{u \cos \theta} \\ &= \frac14 \int \frac{du}{u} = \frac14 \ln|u| +C\\ &= \frac14 \ln|\sin \theta| +C.\end{aligned}\]

To revert back to an expression with \(x\) we have to calculate \(\sin \theta.\)

So we use a reference triangle. The sides \(x\) and \(2\) are given from the substitution \(\tan \theta = x/2.\) With Pythagoras we can then calculate the length of the remaining side of the triangle, which is \(\color{red}\sqrt{x^2+4}\). Hence our final answer is

\[\begin{aligned} \int \frac{dx}{x(x^2+4)} = \frac14 \ln|\sin \theta| +C = \frac{1}{4}\ln\left|\frac{x}{\sqrt{x^2+4}}\right| +C.\end{aligned}\]

We recognize a denominator of the form <math>x^2+a^2</math> and so we attempt a trigonometric substitution of the form

:<math> x = 2\tan \theta, \quad dx = 2\sec^2 \theta\,d\theta.</math>

Then the integral becomes

:<math> \begin{align}
\int \frac{dx}{x(x^2+4)} &= \int \frac{2\sec^2 \theta\,d\theta}{2\tan \theta \underbrace{(4\tan^2\theta+4)}_{=4\sec^2\theta}} \\
&= \int \frac{d\theta}{4\tan\theta} = \frac14 \int \frac{\cos \theta\,d\theta}{\sin \theta}.
\end{align}</math>

To solve this integral we use another substitution:

:<math> u = \sin \theta, \quad du = \cos \theta\,d\theta, </math>

to obtain

:<math> \begin{align}
\frac14 \int \frac{\cos \theta\,d\theta}{\sin \theta} &= \frac14 \int \frac{\cos \theta\,du}{u \cos \theta} \\
&= \frac14 \int \frac{du}{u} = \frac14 \ln|u| +C\\
&= \frac14 \ln|\sin \theta| +C.
\end{align} </math>

To revert back to an expression with <math>x</math> we have to calculate <math>\sin \theta.</math>

[[Image:Math_Exam_Resources_Courses_MATH101_April_2008_Question_3_(c)_picture1.png|150px|right]]

So we use a reference triangle. The sides <math>x</math> and <math>2</math> are given from the substitution <math>\tan \theta = x/2.</math> With Pythagoras we can then calculate the length of the remaining side of the triangle, which is <math>\color{red} \sqrt{x^2+4}</math>. Hence our final answer is

:<math> \int \frac{dx}{x(x^2+4)} = \frac14 \ln|\sin \theta| +C = \frac{1}{4}\ln\left|\frac{x}{\sqrt{x^2+4}}\right| +C. </math>
